For the entire experiment, a single V100 GPU was used.
See Table 10 for the learning rate and training time.
We also show the time spent for decoding source-side of the bilingual parallel corpora for generating synthetic TQE data in Table 10.

S4.T1.caption: Table 1: The number of sentence pairs in the bilingual parallel corpora and synthetic TQE data.
S4.T1.table:
Language pair Bilingual Synthetic
En – De 23,360,441 22,268,661
En – Zh 20,305,268 19,811,665
Ro – En 3,901,501 3,178,631
Et – En 877,769 863,973
Ne – En 498,271 477,563
Si – En 646,766 585,598
references:
The MT outputs for each translation direction had been generated by a Transformer model (Vaswani et al., 2017) trained using the fairseq toolkit333https://github.com/pytorch/fairseq (Ott et al., 2019).444https://github.com/facebookresearch/mlqe/tree/main/nmt_models
Henceforth, according to the size of bilingual parallel corpora used to train the MT models
(Table 1) and we exploit for synthesizing TQE data, we denote
En→→\rightarrowDe and En→→\rightarrowZh as high-resource, Romanian-to-English (Ro→→\rightarrowEn) and Estonian-to-English (Et→→\rightarrowEn) as medium-resource, Nepali-to-English (Ne→→\rightarrowEn) and Sinhalese-to-English (Si→→\rightarrowEn) as low-resource, and the rest as zero-shot555Note that bilingual parallel data for these language pairs could have been used for pre-training. translation directions.

To generate synthetic TQE data, we used M2M-100666https://huggingface.co/facebook/m2m100_418M (Fan et al., 2022) and the bilingual parallel corpora officially provided by the task organizers\@footnotemark (Table 1) on which the aforementioned MT systems had been trained.
Before decoding the source-side of the parallel corpora, we fine-tuned M2M-100 for each translation direction.
First, we sampled 111M, 200200200k, and 505050k sentence pairs for high-, medium-, and low-resource language pairs, respectively, from the bilingual parallel corpora (Table 1),
where we limited parallel sentences to those whose each side was composed of up to 128128128 sub-word tokens.
We then fine-tuned M2M-100 on the sampled parallel sentences with the AdamW optimizer (Loshchilov and Hutter, 2019) (β1=0.9subscript𝛽10.9\beta_{1}=0.9, β2=0.999subscript𝛽20.999\beta_{2}=0.999, ϵ=1×10−8italic-ϵ1superscript108\epsilon=1\times 10^{-8}) on batches of 161616 sentence pairs with a learning rate of 3×10−53superscript1053\times 10^{-5}, and terminated training after one epoch for each of high- and medium-resource language pairs and three epochs for each of low-resource language pairs.
When decoding the source-side of the bilingual parallel corpora, we performed beam search with beam size of 5, length penalty of 1.0, and maximum sequence length of 200.
After decoding, we calculated TER of the MT output with respect to the target-side of the parallel corpus using SacreBLEU777https://github.com/mjpost/sacrebleu (Post, 2018), and composed synthetic tuples of source sentence, MT output, and the TER score, discarding those with TER score greater than 1.01.01.0.
See Table 1 for the results.

Our baselines include three existing unsupervised TQE methods (four models) that do not use synthetic TQE data but bilingual parallel data.
LaBSE is the one explained in Section 2.
While MEAT121212https://github.com/kuro961/MEAT was trained on a smallish parallel corpus in the original work (Kuroda et al., 2022), we trained it on the entire bilingual corpora in Table 1.
As the forced-decoding methods, we compared the original and fine-tuned M2M-100 models.
The latter, denoted as “w/ FT,” were six direction-specific models that are also used for generating synthetic TQE data.

references:
As the pre-trained multilingual encoder, we compared XLM-RBase888https://huggingface.co/xlm-roberta-base (Conneau et al., 2020), XLM-RLarge999https://huggingface.co/xlm-roberta-large, InfoXLMBase101010https://huggingface.co/microsoft/infoxlm-base (Chi et al., 2021), and LaBSE111111https://huggingface.co/sentence-transformers/LaBSE (Feng et al., 2022). The last two have optimized the embedding for [CLS] tokens during pre-training.
Table 2 shows the numbers of parameters of the examined TQE model.
We trained each TQE model with the AdamW optimizer (Loshchilov and Hutter, 2019) (β1=0.9subscript𝛽10.9\beta_{1}=0.9, β2=0.999subscript𝛽20.999\beta_{2}=0.999, ϵ=1×10−8italic-ϵ1superscript108\epsilon=1\times 10^{-8}) on batches of 128 tuples of synthetic TQE data for all the six translation directions, also updating the parameters of the pre-trained multilingual encoder.
We performed early stopping for training with a patience of 333, according to a validation loss calculated for every 101010k steps on a randomly sub-sampled 10%percent1010\% tuples of training data.
We separately trained four models with different learning rates of 5×10−55superscript1055\times 10^{-5}, 1×10−51superscript1051\times 10^{-5}, 5×10−65superscript1065\times 10^{-6}, and 1×10−61superscript1061\times 10^{-6}, and selected the best model for evaluation according to the validation loss.

Table 4 shows our experimental results on the non-zero-shot translation directions.
Some neural TQE models with the “concat” setting outperformed the baselines on the high- and low-resource translation directions.
When compared the two variants based on the same pre-trained models, the “concat” model was consistently superior to the “split” model, suggesting the usefulness of capturing cross-lingual token-level correspondences during encoding, as demonstrated in Ranasinghe et al. (2020).
InfoXLMBase consistently outperformed XLM-RBase.
Considering that both have the same number of parameters and identical vocabulary (see Table 2), this indicates that the [CLS] embedding optimized during pre-training InfoXLMBase helps TQE.
We consider that LaBSE also benefits from the optimized embedding for [CLS].
For most test sets, the larger XLM-R (XLM-RLarge+MLP) outperformed its smaller counterpart (XLM-RBase+MLP), thanks to the larger number of parameters.

Table 4 shows our experimental results on the non-zero-shot translation directions.
Some neural TQE models with the “concat” setting outperformed the baselines on the high- and low-resource translation directions.
When compared the two variants based on the same pre-trained models, the “concat” model was consistently superior to the “split” model, suggesting the usefulness of capturing cross-lingual token-level correspondences during encoding, as demonstrated in Ranasinghe et al. (2020).
InfoXLMBase consistently outperformed XLM-RBase.
Considering that both have the same number of parameters and identical vocabulary (see Table 2), this indicates that the [CLS] embedding optimized during pre-training InfoXLMBase helps TQE.
We consider that LaBSE also benefits from the optimized embedding for [CLS].
For most test sets, the larger XLM-R (XLM-RLarge+MLP) outperformed its smaller counterpart (XLM-RBase+MLP), thanks to the larger number of parameters.

Table 4 shows the results on the zero-shot translation directions.
The “concat” version of TQE models outperformed baselines on En→→\rightarrowCS and Km→→\rightarrowEn,
indicating that synthetic data also help zero-shot TQE depending on translation direction.
Similarly to the results in Table 4, we observed that the following factors affect performance: (a) encoding methods (“split” models vs. “concat” models), (b) optimization of [CLS] during pre-training (XLM-RBase+MLP (concat) vs. InfoXLMBase+MLP (concat)), and (c) the number of parameters (XLM-RBase+MLP (concat) vs. XLM-RLarge+MLP (concat)).

Our investigation demonstrates that it also applies to TQE models, as shown in Table 8.
We took LaBSE+MLP (concat) and InfoXLMBase+MLP (concat) according to their superior results in Table 4, compared two variants of these models trained exclusively on synthetic TQE data for multiple (#TD=6, Section 4) or single (#TD=1, (Fomicheva et al., 2020; Tuan et al., 2021; Eo et al., 2021)) translation directions on the same TQE task as in Section 4, and confirmed that the former outperformed the latter on most translation directions.

Tables 7 and 7 show experimental results on six translation directions in the WMT20 and WMT21 TQE Task 1 test sets, respectively.
InfoXLMBase+MLP (concat) predicted DA scores on high-resource translation directions better than all the baseline models.
In contrast, for middle-resource and low-resource translation directions, none of the neural TQE models trained on synthetic data outperformed MEAT, except for LaBSE+MLP (concat) for Si→→\rightarrowEn in WMT21 test set.

Table 7 shows the results on the zero-shot translation directions.
XLM-RLarge+MLP (concat) and LaBSE+MLP (concat) outperformed two of three baselines in all the translation directions except for En→→\rightarrowCs, but did not outperform MEAT.

Our investigation demonstrates that it also applies to TQE models, as shown in Table 8.
We took LaBSE+MLP (concat) and InfoXLMBase+MLP (concat) according to their superior results in Table 4, compared two variants of these models trained exclusively on synthetic TQE data for multiple (#TD=6, Section 4) or single (#TD=1, (Fomicheva et al., 2020; Tuan et al., 2021; Eo et al., 2021)) translation directions on the same TQE task as in Section 4, and confirmed that the former outperformed the latter on most translation directions.
